questions.text: Unique identifiers are employed to facilitate linking of commonly used data (e.g UPRN for property data).
questions.help: Unique identifiers are employed to facilitate linking of commonly used data (e.g UPRN for property data).

questions.text: The organisation has clear standards in place to inform how commonly used data is recorded (e.g. address or names).
questions.help: The organisation has clear standards in place to inform how commonly used data is recorded (e.g. address or names).

questions.text: Is the quality of data regularly problematic in terms of frequent and/or repeatable operations?
questions.help: Is the quality of data regularly problematic in terms of frequent and/or repeatable operations?

questions.text: Does your organisation have repeatable/documented processes to undertake the most frequent data operations?
questions.help: Does your organisation have repeatable/documented processes to undertake the most frequent data operations?

questions.text: What does the function of data architecture do in your organisation (if it exists)?
questions.help: What does the function of data architecture do in your organisation (if it exists)?

questions.text: How easy is to access and explore organisational data?
questions.help: How easy is to access and explore organisational data?

questions.text: Do you have access to all of your data collected in externally contracted services?
questions.help: Do you have access to all of your data collected in externally contracted services?

questions.text: What is the most commonly used method of data collection and entry?
questions.help: What is the most commonly used method of data collection and entry?

questions.text: To what extent is data collection automated?
questions.help: To what extent is data collection automated?

questions.text: The purpose of data collection is clearly articulated and understood in the majority of cases by the majority of staff
questions.help: The purpose of data collection is clearly articulated and understood in the majority of cases by the majority of staff

questions.text: The organisation collects data for which there is no clear rationale.
questions.help: The organisation collects data for which there is no clear rationale.

questions.text: Do you measure data quality, if so, do you set your metrics and who monitors them?
questions.help: Do you measure data quality, if so, do you set your metrics and who monitors them?

questions.text: Is there executive or senior-level ownership over the data management process?
questions.help: Is there executive or senior-level ownership over the data management process?

questions.text: How does data support evidence-based decision making?
questions.help: How does data support evidence-based decision making?

questions.text: Data is used to inform decision-making across all levels of the organisation - from operational decisions on the front line to strategic decisions in the executive office.
questions.help: Data is used to inform decision-making across all levels of the organisation - from operational decisions on the front line to strategic decisions in the executive office.

questions.text: How is data used to evaluate services and performance?
questions.help: How is data used to evaluate services and performance?

questions.text: How is data used to optimise processes and improve services?
questions.help: How is data used to optimise processes and improve services?

questions.text: How is data presented in the organisation?
questions.help: How is data presented in the organisation?

questions.text: Data and analysis are communicated in accessible formats that are easily understood by non-experts
questions.help: Data and analysis are communicated in accessible formats that are easily understood by non-experts

questions.text: Data analysis is most frequently requested after a decision has been made, as evidence to support the decision.
questions.help: Data analysis is most frequently requested after a decision has been made, as evidence to support the decision.

questions.text: How is data shared across the organisation, for the purpose of analysis?
questions.help: How is data shared across the organisation, for the purpose of analysis?

questions.text: How is data sharing perceived by the organisation?
questions.help: How is data sharing perceived by the organisation?

questions.text: Is there an executive-level member in the organisation who is responsible for data governance and who is positive in driving data sharing?
questions.help: Is there an executive-level member in the organisation who is responsible for data governance and who is positive in driving data sharing?

questions.text: Changes to information governance legislation are understood and planned for in advance.
questions.help: Changes to information governance legislation are understood and planned for in advance.

questions.text: How complete is your Information Asset Register (IAR), and how often is it reviewed and updated?
questions.help: How complete is your Information Asset Register (IAR), and how often is it reviewed and updated?

questions.text: Has a permanent owner for the Information Asset Register been appointed?
questions.help: Has a permanent owner for the Information Asset Register been appointed?

questions.text: Does the organisation rely on outsourcing data-related competencies?
questions.help: Does the organisation rely on outsourcing data-related competencies?

questions.text: Does the organisation provide or offer access to any data-related training? Is training mandated or  purely voluntary?
questions.help: Does the organisation provide or offer access to any data-related training? Is training mandated or  purely voluntary?

questions.text: The number of data analysts (or similar role) is sufficient to meet the analytic demands of the organisation.
questions.help: The number of data analysts (or similar role) is sufficient to meet the analytic demands of the organisation.

questions.text: The organisation has invested in tools and systems that have helped to augment the analytic capacity of the organisation.
questions.help: The organisation has invested in tools and systems that have helped to augment the analytic capacity of the organisation.

questions.text: How closely do data analysts (and similar roles) work with delivery, strategy and other teams?
questions.help: How closely do data analysts (and similar roles) work with delivery, strategy and other teams?

questions.text: What is the organisations approach/capability around data analytics?
questions.help: What is the organisations approach/capability around data analytics?

questions.text: Political leaders have made statements that clearly demonstrate a high level of buy-in and understanding of using data more intelligently.
questions.help: Political leaders have made statements that clearly demonstrate a high level of buy-in and understanding of using data more intelligently.

questions.text: Clear and explicit policies and/or strategies are in place to support greater and more intelligent use of data.
questions.help: Clear and explicit policies and/or strategies are in place to support greater and more intelligent use of data.

questions.text: How would you describe the level of organisational awareness of the value of data?
questions.help: How would you describe the level of organisational awareness of the value of data?

questions.text: There are procurement policies in place that are tailored specifcially to data and analytics projects.
questions.help: There are procurement policies in place that are tailored specifcially to data and analytics projects.

questions.text: There is opportunity and time for data analysts (and similar roles) to engage in analytic work beyond their immediate job requirements.
questions.help: There is opportunity and time for data analysts (and similar roles) to engage in analytic work beyond their immediate job requirements.

questions.text: The organisation has strong data strategy in place, which has been well communicated.
questions.help: The organisation has strong data strategy in place, which has been well communicated.

questions.text: Our data strategy is embedded in wider policy documents.
questions.help: Our data strategy is embedded in wider policy documents.

old.question:
There was an Old Man with a beard,
Who said, 'It is just as I feared!
Two Owls and a Hen,
Four Larks and a Wren,
Have all built their nests in my beard!'
old.help: She handed him a washcloth and went out. As soon as she left, Sammy reclaimed a few precious inches of mattress while his cousin stood there, rubbing at his mauled cheeks. After a moment, Mrs. Klayman switched off the light in the kitchen, and they were left in darkness. Sammy heard his cousin take a deep breath and slowly let it out The stack of newsprint rattled and then hit the floor with a heavy thud of defeat. His jacket buttons clicked against the back of a chair; his trousers rustled as he stepped out of them; he let fall one shoe, then the other. His wristwatch chimed against the water glass on the nightstand. Then he and a gust of chilly air got in under the covers, bearing with them an odor of cigarette, armpit, damp wool, and something sweet and somehow nostalgic that Sammy presently identified as the smell, on his cousin's breath, of prunes from the leftover ingot of his mother's "special" meatloaf--prunes were only a small part of what made it so very special--which he had seen her wrap like a parcel in a sheet of wax paper and set on a plate in the Frigidaire. So she had known that her nephew would be arriving tonight, had even been expecting him for supper, and had said nothing about it to Sammy.

old.question:
And some time later, Iorek Byrnison stepped through the blackened undergrowth and the heat-split rocks at the edge of a burnt forest. The sun was glaring through the smoky haze, but he ignored the heat as he ignored the charcoal dust that blackened his white fur and the midges that searched in vain for skin to bite.
He had come a long way, and at one point in his journey, he had found himself swimming into that other world. He noticed the change in the taste of the water and the temperature of the air, but the air was still good to breathe, and the water still held his body up, so he swam on, and now he had left the sea behind, and he was nearly at the place Serafina Pekkala had described. He cast around, his black eyes gazing up at the sun-shimmering rocks of a wall of limestone crags above him.
old.help: Josef Kavalier settled back against the mattress, cleared his throat once, tucked his arms under his head, and then, as if he had been unplugged, stopped moving. He neither tossed nor fidgeted nor even so much as flexed a toe. The Big Ben on the nightstand ticked loudly. Josef's breathing thickened and slowed. Sammy was just wondering if anyone could possibly fall asleep with such abandon when his cousin spoke.

old.question:
There was a Young Lady of Ryde,
Whose shoe-strings were seldom untied.
She purchased some clogs,
And some small spotted dogs,
And frequently walked about Ryde.
old.help: Presently, his breathing grew steady and slowed to a congested rattle, leaving Sammy to ponder alone, as he did every night, the usual caterpillar schemes. But in his imaginings, Sammy found that, for the first time in years, he was able to avail himself of the help of a confederate.

old.question:
There was an Old Man with a nose,
Who said, 'If you choose to suppose,
That my nose is too long,
You are certainly wrong!'
That remarkable Man with a nose.
old.help:
There was an Old Lady of Chertsey,
Who made a remarkable curtsey;
She twirled round and round,
Till she sunk underground,
Which distressed all the people of Chertsey.

old.question:
There was an Old Man in a tree,
Who was horribly bored by a Bee;
When they said, 'Does it buzz?'
He replied, 'Yes, it does!'
'It's a regular brute of a Bee!'
old.help:
There was an Old Lady of Chertsey,
Who made a remarkable curtsey;
She twirled round and round,
Till she sunk underground,
Which distressed all the people of Chertsey.

old.question:
There was an Old Man with a gong,
Who bumped at it all day long;
But they called out, 'O law!
You're a horrid old bore!'
So they smashed that Old Man with a gong.
